The six unique dimers in the monoclinic crystals formed two essentially indistinguishable hexamers arranged as one turn of an approximately 3-fold screw axis (4Heaslet H.A. Royer W.E. Structure. 1999; 7: 517-526Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). A nearly identical hexameric assemblage is also observed in the deoxy orthorhombic crystals. This suggests that the hexameric assemblages observed in the two crystal types might represent a structure formed in deoxy erythrocytes in vivo. The binding of carbon monoxide to deoxy A-type crystals of lamprey hemoglobin occurs in the absence of subunit dissociation that would occur under protein concentrations used in solution measurements. Apparently, the molecular interactions in the high concentration of the crystal lattice are sufficient to maintain the dimeric contacts upon CO binding. Difference maps (F CO −F deoxy) (Fig. 1 A) directly reveal structural transitions localized in the distal pocket with no significant differences observed on the proximal side. The major effect of CO binding is a movement of the distal histidine (His-73) away from the ligand binding site. This is required because the Nε of His-73 in the deoxy state is about 1.5 Å from the oxygen atom position and 2.4 Å from the carbon atom position of the CO ligand, blocking access to the heme iron. As is apparent from the electron density maps (Fig. 1, B andC), His-73 exhibits significant conformational flexibility following CO binding to lamprey hemoglobin dimers. In contrast, His-73 is well ordered in the structures of deoxy dimers and cyano-met monomer of lamprey hemoglobin. To account for the observed conformational flexibility, two alternate conformations were refined for each of the six monomers in the asymmetric unit. The 12 refined conformations ranged in position from being near the ligand, with the Nε of His-73 as close as 2.8 Å to the oxygen atom of bound ligand (O), to swinging well away from the ligand with this Nε to O distance as high as 7.2 Å. Most subunits were refined with one conformation relatively close to the ligand and one far removed. Even with His-73 in its closest approach to the ligand, the Nε of His-73 would be unable to form a strong stabilizing hydrogen bond with a bound oxygen as the best possible Nε-Hε-O angle would be about 120°. In sharp contrast with the monomer structure (6Honzatko R.B. Hendrickson W.A. Love W.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1985; 184: 147-164Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar), the position of the E-helix in the dimeric form prevents His-73 from attaining a conformation that could form a strong hydrogen bond with a bound oxygen (Figs.4 and5). The 12 conformations of His-73 modeled in the CO-ligated structure differ by rotation around the Cα-Cβ and Cβ-Cγ bonds (Fig. 4 B). Although the resolution limit of our analysis precludes precise modeling of the alternate conformers for His-73, a comparison of the six subunits per asymmetric unit clearly indicates the mobility of this residue. With the results presented here, structures are now available for three alternate forms of lamprey hemoglobin. These include a high affinity ligated monomer (CN-met (6Honzatko R.B. Hendrickson W.A. Love W.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1985; 184: 147-164Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar)), two structures of the unligated low affinity dimer, and the structure of a CO-ligated low affinity dimer. A comparison of these three forms provides plausible structural explanations for the observed functional properties. Equilibrium and kinetic measurements of ligand binding along with ultracentrifugation experiments have shown that modulation of oxygen affinity results from the equilibrium between low affinity oligomers, stabilized by proton binding, and higher affinity monomers, stabilized by oxygen binding (18Briehl R.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1963; 238: 2361-2366Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar, 19Andersen M.E. Gibson Q.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1971; 246: 4790-4799Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20Dohi Y. Sugita Y. Yoneyama Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1973; 248: 2354-2363Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). As a result, ligand affinity is sharply dependent upon pH and protein concentration. The oxygen affinity of the monomeric state, estimated from measurements at a low concentration and higher pH, corresponds to a p50 of ∼5 torr for adult lamprey hemoglobins (19Andersen M.E. Gibson Q.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1971; 246: 4790-4799Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20Dohi Y. Sugita Y. Yoneyama Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1973; 248: 2354-2363Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Qiu Y. Maillett D.H. Knapp J. Olson J.S. Riggs A.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 13517-13528Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). This indicates that lamprey hemoglobin has rather low oxygen affinity even in the monomeric form. This relatively low affinity of the monomer has been suggested to result from a suboptimal orientation of the proximal histidine relative to the heme with a possible contribution from tight packing of residues in the distal pocket (6Honzatko R.B. Hendrickson W.A. Love W.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1985; 184: 147-164Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). At a higher concentration and low pH from which a much higher fraction will be oligomeric, very low oxygen affinities are observed with p50 values reported as high as 68 torr for hemoglobin from Petromyzon marinus (5Wald G. Riggs A. J. Gen. Physiol. 1951; 35: 45-53Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar) and 350 torr for hemoglobin from a related lamprey, Entosphenus japonicus (20Dohi Y. Sugita Y. Yoneyama Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1973; 248: 2354-2363Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A comparison of the four known lamprey hemoglobin structures indicate that the difference in affinity between monomeric and oligomeric forms result from alterations in the distal pocket that occur upon dimerization. Each E-helix moves by ∼1 Å toward the ligand binding distal pocket upon dimerization, and the distal histidine crowds an already tight pocket, such that it sterically restricts access to the ligand binding site of the deoxy dimer. This restricted distal pocket provides an explanation for the very low oxygen (0.25 × 106m−1 sec−1) and CO (0.12 × 106m−1 sec−1) combination rate constants in the dimer (19Andersen M.E. Gibson Q.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1971; 246: 4790-4799Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) among the lowest known combination rate constants for any hemoglobin. Dissociation into monomers results in a 40-fold increase in oxygen and 8-fold increase in CO combination rate constants. Structural comparisons indicate that dissociation results from the movement of the E-helix and His-73 away from the ligand binding site, permitting a more optimal stereochemistry for ligand binding. There is also evidence that oxygen dissociation rate constants are somewhat higher at a lower pH, although a firm estimate of the dissociation rate constant for a dimer has not been obtained (19Andersen M.E. Gibson Q.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1971; 246: 4790-4799Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Our structure of a CO-ligated dimer provides a rationale for these results as His-73 would be unable to form a stabilizing hydrogen bond with bound oxygen in the lamprey hemoglobin dimer but would be able to stabilize bound oxygen in the monomeric form. A comparison of the crystal structures of lamprey hemoglobin indicates that the key residue involved in regulating oxygen affinity in lamprey hemoglobin is His-73. By linking its conformation to oligomeric state, His-73 appears to play a dual role in modulating affinity between monomeric and dimeric forms. In the unligated dimer, its steric restriction of ligand access to the heme binding site acts to lower combination rates and thus oxygen affinity. In addition, the ability of His-73 to form a stabilizing hydrogen bond with bound oxygen in the monomer but not the dimer will enhance the affinity of the monomer relative to that of the dimer. Another residue previously suggested to be involved in the low affinity binding of the deoxy state was Ile-77 (4Heaslet H.A. Royer W.E. Structure. 1999; 7: 517-526Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Upon CO binding to the dimer, this side chain can adopt the conformation observed in the monomeric form of lamprey hemoglobin, suggesting it is less important in the distal regulation of oxygen affinity (Fig. 4 A). The conformational flexibility that we observe for the distal histidine in these crystals is reminiscent of observed motions in mammalian myoglobins. In sperm whale myoglobin, the distal histidine has been shown to swing out of the distal pocket at pH 4.0, opening a direct channel from the solvent to ligand binding site (22Yang F. Phillips Jr., G.N. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 256: 762-774Crossref PubMed Scopus (300) Google Scholar). Additionally, the time-averaged crystallographic refinement of a myoglobin mutant (F46V) indicates that the distal histidine undergoes a swinging motion between the heme pocket and solvent (23Romo T.D. Clarage J.B. Sorensen D.C. Phillips Jr., G.N. Proteins. 1995; 22: 311-321Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Recent near-atomic resolution structures of myoglobin also provide evidence of such distal histidine motion (24Vojtechovsky J. Chu K. Berendzen J. Sweet R.M. Schlichting I. Biophys. J. 1999; 77: 2153-2174Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (496) Google Scholar, 25Kachalova G.S. Popov A.N. Bartunik H.D. Science. 1999; 284: 473-479Crossref PubMed Scopus (303) Google Scholar). These observed distal histidine movements represent a functionally important motion suggested to provide a kinetic pathway for ligand to travel into and out of the distal pocket (26Scott E.E. Gibson Q.H. Olson J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 5177-5188Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (333) Google Scholar). It has been shown that the stretching frequency of CO bound to myoglobin is very dependent on the environment of the CO, particularly the position of the distal histidine (27Li T. Quillin M.L. Phillips G.N. Olson J.S. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 1433-1446Crossref PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar). This suggests that performing infrared spectra measurements on an assembled form of lamprey hemoglobin could test the multiple conformations of the distal histidine that we observe in these crystals upon CO-binding. As discussed above, a comparison of the four crystal structures of lamprey hemoglobin reveal key structural differences in the distal (ligand binding) pocket that provide plausible structural explanations for the observed functional differences between monomeric and dimeric forms. In contrast, there are no significant changes in the proximal region upon dimerization or upon binding of CO in the oligomeric state at the resolution of our analysis. These observations indicate that oxygen affinity in lamprey hemoglobin is distally regulated with His-73 playing key roles in the differences in ligand binding properties between the dimer and monomer forms. The distal control of ligand affinity in lamprey hemoglobin contrasts with other cooperative hemoglobins. For instance, in the homodimeric hemoglobin (HbI) from the blood clam Scapharca, the movement of the heme iron into the heme plane is restricted by the packing of Phe-97 against the proximal side of the heme (Fig.6, top panel) (2Royer Jr., W.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 235: 657-681Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). When ligand binds, the side chain of Phe-97 is displaced from the heme pocket, allowing the proximal histidine to move toward the heme group and the heme iron to move into the heme plane. The changes at the distal side of HbI are small compared with to those observed in the proximal pocket. In contrast, lamprey hemoglobin V dimerization exhibits a more direct effect on the ligand binding site. There is a close coupling between the conformation of His-73 and that of Trp-72 from which side-chain conformation undergoes major rearrangement as it is buried in the dimer interface (Fig. 6, bottom panel). Our present work, in which deoxy crystals of lamprey hemoglobin are exposed to carbon monoxide, shows significant structural rearrangements at the distal side of the heme with no observable changes at the proximal side (Figs. 4 and 5). This work strongly supports the hypothesis that the oxygen affinity in lamprey hemoglobin is distally regulated. An important test of the proposed structural mechanism for regulation of lamprey hemoglobin has been mutagenesis carried out by Qui et al. (21Qiu Y. Maillett D.H. Knapp J. Olson J.S. Riggs A.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 13517-13528Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). Nine mutants were expressed and subjected to sedimentation equilibrium and oxygen binding experiments to probe the role of individual residues in the assembly and regulation of oxygen affinity. The mutation of key residues at the dimeric interface, namely Tyr-30, Glu-31, Glu-75, and Asn-79, either decreased the stability of lamprey hemoglobin dimers or completely abolished dimerization. Consistent with the lower oxygen affinity of the dimer (18Briehl R.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1963; 238: 2361-2366Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar), the dimer destabilizing mutants also showed higher oxygen affinity. Mutation of the distal His to Gln resulted in significantly increased oxygen affinity unlike the decreased affinity in the equivalent mutation in mammalian myoglobins and hemoglobins along with a decrease in dimer stability. Thus, the effects of this mutation could result from a combination of a removal of steric effects at the ligand binding site and disruption of the interface. It is also interesting to note that the mutation of Glu-75 to Gln decreased the number of protons released/heme by half, relative to the wild type and consistent with the involvement of this residue in the Bohr effect suggested by our structural results. Thus, these results strongly support the mechanism proposed earlier (4Heaslet H.A. Royer W.E. Structure. 1999; 7: 517-526Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar) and extended here. These studies provide a structural basis for understanding an exquisite interface design that balances favorable and unfavorable interactions, such that binding of protons or oxygen can drive oligomerization or subunit dissociation.
